<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_bus_close:
```c
static void metal_linux_bus_close(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	struct linux_bus *lbus = to_linux_bus(bus);
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		if (ldrv->sdrv)
			sysfs_close_driver(ldrv->sdrv);
		ldrv->sdrv = NULL;
	}

	sysfs_close_bus(lbus->sbus);
	lbus->sbus = NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_linux_bus_close:
static struct linux_bus *to_linux_bus(struct metal_bus *bus)
{
	return metal_container_of(bus, struct linux_bus, bus);
}
...
static int metal_linux_probe_bus(struct linux_bus *lbus)
{
	struct linux_driver *ldrv;
	int ret, error = -ENODEV;

	lbus->sbus = sysfs_open_bus(lbus->bus_name);
	if (!lbus->sbus)
		return -ENODEV;

	for_each_linux_driver(lbus, ldrv) {
		ret = metal_linux_probe_driver(lbus, ldrv);
		/* Clear the error if any driver is available */
		if (!ret)
			error = ret;
	}

	if (error) {
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);
		return error;
	}

	error = metal_linux_register_bus(lbus);
	if (error)
		metal_linux_bus_close(&lbus->bus);

	return error;
}
</additional code>

explanation: Fragments not listed do not need investigation for Rule 17.2 because they cannot produce direct or indirect recursion by themselves: to_linux_bus() is a simple container_of wrapper (no calls to other project functions shown); simple assignments (e.g., ldrv->sdrv = NULL; lbus->sbus = NULL) and local variable declarations are non-calling operations; the for_each_linux_driver iteration construct by itself only enumerates drivers and does not imply a call-cycle unless the functions called inside it (which are listed above) do so. The suspicious fragments provided include all call sites in the shown code that could participate in a recursive call chain (calls to sysfs_* helpers, metal_linux_probe_driver, metal_linux_register_bus, and the calls to metal_linux_bus_close). Those called functions' implementations (not provided) must be inspected to determine whether any direct or indirect recursion occurs.
